metadata.description: Scientific knowledge graph exploring the relationship between gut microbiome composition and clinical depression

nodes.label: Smith et al. (2019): Gut-Brain Axis Review

metadata.title: The Gut-Brain Axis: A Comprehensive Review of Bidirectional Communication
metadata.abstract: This comprehensive review examines the bidirectional communication between the gut microbiome and the central nervous system. We analyze evidence from 47 studies demonstrating that gut bacteria produce neurotransmitters including serotonin, dopamine, and GABA that can influence brain function through the vagus nerve.

nodes.label: Chen et al. (2020): Probiotic RCT

metadata.title: Probiotic Supplementation Reduces Depression: A 12-Week Randomized Controlled Trial
metadata.abstract: In this 12-week randomized controlled trial with 200 participants, we demonstrate that daily probiotic supplementation (Lactobacillus rhamnosus) significantly reduced PHQ-9 depression scores compared to placebo (mean difference: 3.2, p < 0.01). Participants showed 40% greater improvement than control group.

nodes.label: Lee et al. (2022): No Probiotic Effect

metadata.title: No Effect of Probiotics on Depression: A Large Multi-Center Trial
metadata.abstract: In our multi-center trial with 1,200 participants across 8 sites, we found no significant effect of probiotic supplementation on depression scores (mean difference: 0.8, p = 0.34). The smaller sample size and single-site design of previous positive studies may have inflated effect sizes.

nodes.label: Johnson et al. (2021): Microbiome Diversity

metadata.title: Reduced Gut Microbiome Diversity in Major Depressive Disorder
metadata.abstract: Analysis of gut microbiome samples from 500 patients with MDD and 500 healthy controls revealed significantly reduced bacterial diversity (Shannon index: 2.1 vs 3.4, p < 0.001) in depressed individuals. Specific depletion of Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium species was observed.

nodes.label: Wilson et al. (2018): Vagus Nerve Pathway

metadata.title: The Vagus Nerve as a Mediator of Gut-Brain Communication in Depression
metadata.abstract: We demonstrate that the vagus nerve serves as the primary pathway for gut-brain communication. Vagotomized mice showed no antidepressant effects from probiotic treatment, while sham-operated controls showed significant improvement. This establishes the vagal pathway as essential for microbiome-mood effects.

nodes.label: Patel et al. (2023): Inflammation Mediator

metadata.title: Gut Dysbiosis Drives Depression Through Systemic Inflammation
metadata.abstract: Our study reveals that gut dysbiosis triggers systemic inflammation, which in turn affects brain function. We found elevated IL-6 and TNF-alpha levels in depressed patients correlated with reduced microbiome diversity (r = -0.67, p < 0.001). Anti-inflammatory treatment partially reversed depressive symptoms.

nodes.label: Taylor et al. (2020): Diet-Microbiome Link

metadata.title: Mediterranean Diet Improves Mood via Gut Microbiome Modulation
metadata.abstract: A 6-month intervention study with 150 participants demonstrated that adherence to Mediterranean diet increased beneficial gut bacteria by 45% and reduced depression scores by 32%. Microbiome changes preceded mood improvements by 2-4 weeks, suggesting a causal pathway.

nodes.label: Miller et al. (2017): Foundational Review

metadata.title: The Microbiome-Gut-Brain Axis: From Bowel to Behavior
metadata.abstract: This foundational review synthesizes evidence for the microbiome-gut-brain axis. We propose a model where gut bacteria influence behavior through four pathways: neural (vagus), endocrine (HPA axis), immune (cytokines), and metabolic (short-chain fatty acids).

nodes.label: Garcia et al. (2024): Meta-Analysis

metadata.title: Probiotics for Depression: A Meta-Analysis of 42 RCTs
metadata.abstract: Meta-analysis of 42 randomized controlled trials (n=4,851) reveals a small but significant effect of probiotics on depression (SMD = 0.34, 95% CI: 0.12-0.56). Effect sizes were larger in studies with clinical populations (SMD = 0.52) versus healthy volunteers (SMD = 0.18). Publication bias was detected.

nodes.label: Zhang et al. (2023): Skeptical Review

metadata.title: Questioning the Gut-Depression Link: Methodological Concerns
metadata.abstract: We critically examine 35 studies claiming gut-depression links. Major methodological issues include: small sample sizes (median n=78), lack of dietary controls, inconsistent bacterial assessments, and failure to account for medication effects. Only 4/35 studies met rigorous quality criteria.

nodes.label: Nakamura et al. (2021): SCFA Mechanism

metadata.title: Short-Chain Fatty Acids Modulate Serotonin Synthesis in the Gut
metadata.abstract: We demonstrate that short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) produced by gut bacteria directly stimulate serotonin synthesis in enterochromaffin cells. Butyrate supplementation increased gut serotonin levels by 180% in germ-free mice. Since 90% of body serotonin is gut-derived, this pathway may influence mood.

nodes.label: Martinez et al. (2022): FMT Study

metadata.title: Fecal Microbiota Transplant Alleviates Treatment-Resistant Depression
metadata.abstract: In this open-label pilot study, 12 patients with treatment-resistant depression received fecal microbiota transplant from healthy donors. 8/12 (67%) showed significant improvement at 8 weeks (>50% reduction in HAM-D scores). Responders showed increased Bifidobacterium levels post-transplant.
